Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Template Strategies for the Alignment of Nanoparticle Chains
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nanotechnology has rapidly infiltrated the technology of people's daily lives. From portable electronics, to medicine and energy; this ultra-small class of structures is having a gigantic impact. In order to realize many of the electrical, thermal and chemical properties of such structures, it is essential to investigate more complicated arrangements of nanostrucutres. Though many methods are being investigated, most are exceedingly novel, difficult to scale up, and expensive. Strategies which combine both proven technologies as well as novel engineering are ideal. This research will employ a developed nano-template technology and a new method of polymer-mediated nanoparticle synthesis to create chains of nanoparticles of specific width and length. This research will be conducted in collaboration with Dr. Kohji Ohno, an expert in polymer synthesis and surface chemistry, at Kyoto University in Kyoto, Japan. Ultimately, this research will serve as an initial investigation that can be readily adapted to the assembly of chains possessing different and useful properties. This interdisciplinary research has the potential to serve as an inexpensive, scalable source of one dimensional nano-structures applicable in current technologies and required for emerging ones.

This work aims to produce long chains of covalently linked iron oxide (Fe3O4) nanoparticles via magnetic alignment in nano-channels. Surface-functionalized nanoparticles are primarily synthesized via controlled polymerization from several multi-functional initiators. Alignment is achieved by magnetically-directing the particles into aluminum oxide channels where they are photo-crosslinked and removed. Drawing from polymer, chemical and materials science disciplines; this work will be characterized by several techniques including gel permeation chromatography, scanning electron microscopy (SEM), and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). Though this project is limited to iron oxide nanoparticle chains, it is generalizable to more complex systems of nanoparticles with an iron oxide core covered in a shell material (metal, semiconductor, inorganic etc.) to afford additional functionality. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The importance of nanotechnology in our daily lives is already evident in our daily lives. Be it smart phones, advanced medicines, solar cells or batteries; all involve materials engineered on the nanoscale. Besides existing technologies, many new ones will soon be possible as more advanced nanoscale developments are made. To that end, techniques for crafting more complex nanoscale materials are of the utmost importance and the focus of this study. Among many techniques being investigated for nanoscale materials synthesis, a promising strategy involves the use of polymeric templates for the controlled synthesis of regular nanoscale particles of many different compositions.

This project employed advanced polymerization techniques to craft uniform star-like polymer structures possessing many long arms radiating from a central core. Different types of polymers were linked together to create a mixed-arm structure. The inner block can coordinate metal ions whereas the outer block serves to shield the inner core and give them a spherical shape. These structures were used to craft nanoscale inorganic particles composed of iron oxide in a manner analogous to concentrating positively-charged species around a negatively-charged point. Several well-defined polymeric structures were produced and used to synthesize nanoscale structures.

These nanoscale particles can then be organized into chains through the use of hard inorganic templates resembling tubes. The method of alignment is derived from the magnetic core of the structures which can be directed through the simple external application of a magnetic field.  Furthermore, the cores can be permanently linked through chemical reaction within the tubes. The resulting materials may possess interesting magnetic properties due to their complex shape. Furthermore, more complex nanoscale materials composed of an inner magnetic core and outer functional shell can be readily produced in a similar manner. The composition of the outer functional layer can be many different materials and thus possess many different properties which are anisotropic (directionally-dependent) in nature and be applied to many broad areas within electronics, energy and medicine.


Last Modified: 03/05/2015
Modified by: James A Iocozzia
